awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Microbial Fermentation Bioprocess to Produce and Extract Platform Chemicals from the Dairy Industry Acid Whey Waste Stream.
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to commercialize a novel fermentation technology offering a sustainable solution for dairy industry waste issues. The system is initially focused on upcycling acid whey waste from Greek yogurt production into treated water and natural food-grade bio-oils that are sustainable alternatives for chemicals sourced from palm oil. These systems will be installed on-site at yogurt plants and are expected to lower customer expenses by at least 20%, while also reducing greenhouse gas emissions and energy consumption by 90%. This pilot project will inform treatment of other problematic wastes, such as process line cleaning water and manure, as well as milk and cheese processing byproducts. The bio-oils produced this way could serve as animal feed and as drop-in alternatives for biofuels. 

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to optimize the system design of a novel fermentation technology.  Evaluations are focused on upcycling acid whey waste from Greek yogurt production into treated water and bio-oil.  Project objectives include: 1) bench-scale evaluations on bioreactor architecture and operating parameters, such as internal packing materials, gas dosing flowrates, and pH control; 2) bench-scale mass transfer optimizations performed on the current bio-oil extraction architecture, as well as on a novel membrane-less alternative. Results from bench-scale studies will inform process design and construction of a 2,000-gallon demonstration system installed at a Greek yogurt plant, where parallel bioprocesses will systematically evaluate operational parameters (temperature,  pH, flow) at a larger scale to explore the trade space of acid whey treatment,  production of bio-oil, and operating cost and optimize the operating parameters.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Food waste disposal incurs a significant cost on food processors, and releases considerable amounts of greenhouse gases using today’s typical disposal practices, like anaerobic digestion. Instead of producing low value biogas through anaerobic digestion, Capro-X’s WheyAway fermentation platform uses natural microbial communities to transforms food waste into treated water and high-value fatty acid biochemicals that compete directly with unsustainable palm oil chemicals.

 

Activities

Capro-X’s efforts in this Phase 2 project built directly on results of the Phase 1 identifying operational optimizations to maximize fatty acid production efficiency at the bench-scale (1-gallon). The work in this project continued bench evaluations and critically evaluating performance at the 2,000-gallon Demonstration size. At the bench, the company executed efforts to optimize the WheyAway by performing evaluations of a single-stage fermentation process, as opposed to the typical two-stage bioprocess design; we evaluated the fermentation at different temperatures, pHs, and gas inclusion rates; we identified a number of operating criteria (flow, pressure, temperature, chemical species) to optimize the fatty acid extraction system; and we evaluated a new continuous chemical extraction system architecture which lowers capital cost significantly by eliminating the use of membranes.

 

In total, Capro-X has collected multiple years’ of operating data from bench-scale systems, including a long-running bioprocess operating since the Phase 1 project with 1,000 days of continuous operation. All of these efforts culminated to inform in-house design and construction of the first WheyAway Demonstration system – a 2,000-gallon research pilot featuring triplicate fatty acid bioreactors. The company operated the Demonstration system on-site at a local Greek yogurt plant, and collected >1 of operating data. Ultimately, the Demonstration system utilized an industrial-scale chemical extraction system for the first time, demonstrated performance at a TRL 6, and proved long term compatibility with common materials of construction and standard industrial equipment.

 

Outcomes

The results at the bench demonstrated a significant improvement to Phase 1 results, yielding a > 100% increase in net operating margin, thanks to increased biochemical production and extraction rates. The Demonstration system demonstrated highly promising results, even with the expected lower efficiency of a first scale-up: compared to the bench-scale optima, we observed a ~15% increase in opex and capex, which resulted in a payback period of ~4.5 years. In total, the company’s efforts throughout this Phase 2 project demonstrate high likelihood that the WheyAway can be scaled to large sizes and should be scaled another 10x as soon as possible, at which point the company can begin selling fatty acid products that exceed customer requirements and are priced competitively with products already on the market.

 

Merit

Capro-X’s immediate impact to society is the deployment of the WheyAway, which decreases disposal costs for food producers, and produces carbon-negative biochemicals that replace those from palm, coconut, and petroleum sources. Capro-X is focused on fatty acid production today – these chemicals are considered platform chemicals – they can be transformed through existing pathways into numerous products with ready markets today, such as healthful feed additives, human food and beauty ingredients, industrial solvents, and ultimately biofuel and bioplastic. Ultimately, the potential to apply Capro-X’s WheyAway platform to additional organic feedstocks, such as municipal waste and agricultural residues, provides significant growth potential to replace anaerobic digestion as the de-facto organic waste conversion solution, providing the opportunity to turn waste treatment plants across the US into regional biorefineries producing locally-sourced chemicals, fuels, and plastics. Finally, third party evaluation has identified the WheyAway reduces carbon versus the best solution today – anaerobic digestion – for every ton of organic waste diverted to a Capro-X WheyAway, 1.5 tons of GHG emissions can be reduced; we expect an impact of >2 million tons/yr within a decade.
